You are quite right about the role of humor in this sort of thing. However you're also right about the role of time. 300 years later, I certainly hope people would be able to laugh about things. However I'm not sure I'm not sure I would approach a bunch of people who'd been forcibly baptized yesterday, and say, "Hey, you think those soldiers were bad? You should have seen the nuns who taught CCD back home!" Sure, I think it's funny...

And, I'm somewhat discouraged to say, the events which provoked the recent, minor displays of outrage happened half a millenium ago.

Still, so far, so good, and I hope it remains that way. If I'm shown to be a nervous nancy in this, I'll admit it with good cheer.

[ysth], [localtime://2005-11-02 14:58:34]
I actually was hoping to let people let off a little steam innocuously, hence the negative focus of the question. I thought asking what would be a good level title might explode in acrimony. So far it seems to have worked...

[davido], [localtime://2005-11-02 14:06:15]
[ysth] and I considered and discussed this before letting the poll go live. We discussed allowing Grand Inquisitor to appear, but decided that in the context of (1)A humorous poll, and (2)voting for the least appropriate, it would not ruffle feathers. I'm particularly sensitive to not having a repeat of a previous situation that I was involved in with a poll that I accidentally worded convroversially.

But polls are more interesting if they are somehow relevant to current events, and to that end, the recent overhaul (major news) is excellent fodder, and within reason, fair game, IMHO. We did toss out at least one other option that I decided had a socially negative feeling in modern day. But the inquisiton was a 'hellofa long time ago'.

I was recently in the Philippines on vacation. The Filipinos were overrun by the Spanish for about 300 years, starting when Magellan showed up in Cebu and started "converting" all those asians to Catholicism. I'm sure it wasn't pleasant for those of them who didn't feel a strong personal desire to convert. But now, hundreds of years later, it's the fodder of a light hearted Filipino folk song where they laugh and sing about the day that "Magellan showed up and baptised us all."

Anyway, take heart, [petruchio]; [ysth] and [davido|I] aren't trying to antagonize you or the monastery. If anything a light-hearted poll should help to diffuse the situation by reminding everyone that this is just for fun anyway, and we may as well joke about it. It's human nature to calm our nerves with a little laughter.

[Petruchio], [localtime://2005-11-02 09:22:00]
Given the emotional nature of the discussions surrounding the historical Grand Inquistiors, I must admit that I was rather hoping to see the topic become less popular soon. I'm not sure prompting for further discussion is altogether prudent.

For that matter, a minority of people are sincerely unhappy with the changes, and several of the poll options were ones they've actually suggested as improvements. This poll seems designed to keep the complaints coming, and keep attention focused on what was inevitably to be a fractious process.

Is there a reason to be focusing on the negative generally?

Update: I don't man this to sound overly harsh. Possibly I'm overstating the significance of this... so far the comments have been innocuous. I just have this vision of [Tanktalus] posting Ode to Torquemada, in which he uses heroic couplets to thank him for inventing the hot air balloon, whereupon the heads several Perlmonk Jews in Exile promptly explode.

[davido], [localtime://2005-07-27 13:11:03]
New entries to the wiki always go at the top, even if they're followups. Dissimilar topics should be separated by an <hr />.

Nothing is ever removed from a wiki. This will be our prepetual record of past polls, to prevent duplication. When the wiki gets rotated we'll have to ask that the new wiki link to the previous, and so on, like a chain of history. That means, when a poll gets posted, all we do is update the wiki to show the post date. But we don't remove anything.

Polls can be posted anytime, but favoring weekdays is fine. The idea is to keep it fresh. Please post the poll queue item to the wiki a day or so in advance so that we don't step on each other. Unless there's protest amongst [pollsters], we'll assume that the next poll in the wiki's queue will be the next one to go up. To keep this simple, let's keep the queue to three polls or less for now.

I don't want to say post only on weekdays because that would eliminate weekends, and there may be times where a weekend-posted poll is the right thing to do. But it's certanly ok to favor weekdays.

Yes, the person posting the poll to the wiki queue will be the one to submit it in the new poll form.

I think a list of poll dates is too structured. Approximately one-week timing is pretty good, but there will be times when we want one sooner, and times where a poll may live longer than a week. There may even be a current event type poll that will jump forward in the queue and bypass the wiki proposal, though those should be few and far between, and they should still be listed in the wiki as they're submitted.

Play it by ear. Too many rules will make it unwieldy. Jump in and have fun.

Using the [new poll] form

Create polls by clicking [new poll]. Fill in the poll's title. Answers should be listed one per line in the multi-line textbox. Poll response options may contain monastery-style HTML. Don't worry about any special poll encoding. Radio buttons and forms are all set up automatically by the poll mechanism. Just put one response option per line.

By default the person posting the poll will be credited as the author. You may select another individual (in case the poll was submitted to [pollsters] by someone else), or you can specify [pollsters] (the group) as the author (use this feature sparingly).

[davido], [localtime://2005-07-25 04:07:06]

Poll scheduling and wiki tracking

New polls should be posted at approximately one-week intervals. This is a higher frequency than we had prior to the existance of [pollsters] as a [Cabal] group, but will serve to keep the polls fresh. If there's time, post the anticipated title and release date to the wiki about a day or more before creating the poll. This will help in the future as [pollsters] grows so that we're not stepping on each others' polls. It will also facilitate comments and discussion in advance of the poll going live. Let's try to keep the queue down to no more than two or three pending polls.

Use this format:
Poll title
[davido] (or whoever you are)
Contributed by: (if applicable)
Proposed release date: mm/dd/yyyy
Released: mm/dd/yyyy as [id://poll's node id]

That way we can easily keep track of how old polls are, what's coming next, etc.

Remember, Monastery polls are just for fun. We're not doing political surveys, evaluating consumer preferences, or any other kind of scientific study. An occasional 'interesting' poll is ok as long as it doesn't attempt to be too serious. In general, keep the polls light-hearted. Avoid subjects that might draw out flame wars.
